summary: The American left demands an Israel-Hamas cease-fire, but on whose terms?. Since Hamas began its rocket offensive last week, the Biden Administration has wisely refused to dictate the Israeli response. But the U.S. narrative war took a notable turn this week as Congressional Democrats demanded a cease-fire. We hope the President bucks his instinct to follow his party and leads it instead.

title: 'Life at the Waterhole' Review: Survival in the Serengeti
summary: A one-of-a-kind camera rig built by PBS and the BBC offers intimate footage of elephants, big cats and other wild animals drawn to a Tanzanian reserve's most precious resource.. Although its subjects include the African wildlife that lives in the Serengeti, "Life at the Waterhole" will have homeowners everywhere sympathizing with the show's furry, feathered cast, and its benefactors as well: You find a nice place to live. Put in a pool. The next thing you know, hyenas move in next door. And there goes the neighborhood.

title: Shrinking Blue States Have 'Defund the Police' to Blame

title: Anatomy of a Good Economic Decision
summary: Policy choices are bets on the future, and Biden needs a plan in case inflation sticks.. Aristotle's account of deliberation had a huge effect on me as an undergraduate, and the ensuing six decades haven't dulled its edge. Here it is in a nutshell: We don't deliberate about mathematical truths or scientific laws. We deliberate about actions within our power, whose consequences cannot be known with certainty. Such realities can inform today's debate around the Biden economic program.

Retreat can have its heroic qualities but not a faintest whiff of heroism attached to AT&T 's retreat Monday from its big Warner Media merger, which it will unwind by shifting the assets to Discovery Inc .

She's even trying to make some emergency workplace rules permanent in the Wolverine State. But for her own life, it seems Gov. title: U.S. Bank Stocks Shine as Investors Bet on Recovery
summary: Some $32 billion has flowed into broad financial stocks in 2021, already a full-year record. Everyone is clamoring for a piece of U.S. banks.

title: 'Too Close' Review: A Case of Psychological Warfare
summary: Emily Watson and Denise Gough star in a cerebral thriller from AMC+ about the conflict between a forensic psychiatrist and a hostile patient with amnesia accused of a horrific crime.. Putting the perverse in reverse psychology, "Too Close" is a cerebral thriller aimed a bit more at the mind than the pulse. It also involves a crime usually considered insufficient for a multi-episode crime series, namely attempted murder. Only attempted? We're grateful for small favors: On a night of teeming North London rain, Connie Mortensen (Denise Gough) drives through a drawbridge barricade, taking two small children with her into the water below. Later, she can recall almost nothing. "I can't even remember where we are in our relationship," she says to her husband. "At the end," he says. She does not, understandably, have a lot of friends.

title: A High-Speed Antitrust Failure
summary: AT&T's media spinoff shows how wrong the trustbusters were.. Well, both AT&T's media empire and the government's antitrust case have now unraveled.

summary: Gasoline conduit suffered outages to ordering system Tuesday morning unrelated to recent cyberattack; it was back online by Tuesday afternoon. title: Bill Gates Transfers $850 Million in Deere Shares to Melinda French Gates
summary: Billionaire has disclosed over $3 billion in stock transfers since the couple's May 3 divorce filing. title: Anti-Money-Laundering Whistleblower Program Struggles to Get Off Ground
summary: With no minimum reward setting and program delays, lawyers are reluctant to represent potential tipsters. A new U.S. program to reward those who report possible violations of anti-money-laundering laws has gotten off to a slow start, as some lawyers say the lack of a minimum reward and delays in establishing the systems for receiving and investigating tips have made them reluctant to take on whistleblowers as clients.

title: Internet-Linked Infrastructure Is Not Secure
summary: We have connected nearly every aspect of our lives to this world-wide network. How did we manage to do business before it?. Regarding your editorial "The Real Infrastructure Problem" (May 11): We have connected nearly every aspect of our lives to this world-wide network. How did we manage to do business before it? We used private wire lines and fiber-optic cables, microwave links, and we talked to one another. And why do we now find it necessary that every valve, motor and obscure piece of equipment must be on the internet 24/7? Well, it's very convenient and cheap. And it does give us extraordinarily powerful access to monitor and control far-flung operations. But it also gives the bad guys a gaping hole to enter and do mischief. I suggest we rethink what really needs to be connected, when it needs to be connected and how. The old ways were much harder to hack. I only connect my home computer to the internet when I need it. The connection goes through an old-fashioned knife switch that is off most of the time, denying the bad guys access. They haven't yet figured out how to throw a knife switch remotely.

title: Southlake Demands the Truth, Not Wokeness
summary: We are not motivated by any issues other than what is right for our children.. Regarding your editorial "Southlake Says No to Woke Education" (May 8): As the retiring mayor of Southlake, Texas, I can say the Southlake community's response is about caring for all students and the desire to teach truth and human decency. Southlake has been wrongly attacked by outsiders with other agendas. We are not motivated by any issues other than what is right for our children.

title: No-Ownership Society and Reliable Electric Power
summary: While interconnection is great, so is resiliency and the ability to be independent during emergencies.. In "The No-Ownership Society" (Inside View, May 10), Andy Kessler reminds us how tenuous our "ownership" of devices that we've bought and paid for is. He's only scratched the surface. I am responsible for two solar-power systems, one on my roof, the other at work. Four different vendors supply components of the system, and all four demand an internet connection to monitor and even control the system. There is no reason why these components, already present on my local network, cannot provide data to my desktop computer or phone app, yet they require this gratuitous connection.

title: Biden Will Use Stealth and Crush All the Steakholders
summary: Of course the Democrats are coming after our meat.. Regarding Stephen Moore's "Biden May Make a Big Missed Steak" (op-ed, May 10): Of course the Democrats are coming after our meat. The level of vitriol leveled against the entire industry by the climate police makes it inevitable. But they'll be clever about it. First, it will be pitched as a need for more humane animal farming (common-sense rules). And then new feedstock rules. And then several large liberal states will ban any meat imports from other states that don't follow strict guidelines. They won't ban it outright, they'll make it so expensive that the industry will largely go out of business. This will follow the playbook from the Obama administration on coal plants-they didn't ban them, they made them so expensive that no one would dare build a new one.

title: Andrew Giuliani Declares Run for New York Governor

title: Online Sales Party Starts Winding Down
summary: E-commerce sales are still growing, but could start losing momentum quickly. Online retailing has spent the pandemic bellying up to the bar, but now it might be on the brink of a hangover.

title: Google Aims for Commercial-Grade Quantum Computer by 2029
summary: Tech giant is one of many companies racing to build a business around the nascent technology. Alphabet Inc.'s Google plans to spend several billion dollars to build a quantum computer by 2029 that can perform large-scale business and scientific calculations without errors, said Hartmut Neven, a distinguished scientist at Google who oversees the company's Quantum AI program. The company recently opened an expanded California-based campus focused on the effort, he said.

title: Here's Why Younger Patients Are Accounting for More Covid-19 Hospitalizations
summary: Pandemic fatigue and lower vaccination rates could be contributing factors. Widespread access to Covid-19 vaccines has driven down hospitalizations across all age groups, but national data show the decline hasn't been as steep for people under the age of 50. Americans between the ages of 18 and 49 make up 36% of hospitalizations-a 15.5 percentage-point increase from the start of 2021, according to a CDC surveillance system that draws data from numerous states. Here are three reasons younger Americans are making up more of the Covid-19 hospitalizations, even as the U.S. inches closer to a full reopening.

title: President Biden Supports Cease-Fire in Call With Netanyahu
summary: Resume Subscription. TEL AVIV-President Biden voiced support for a cease-fire in a call with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as Israel said airstrikes in the Gaza Strip targeted a tunnel network used by Hamas amid rising civilian casualties in the conflict.

title: AT&T to Combine WarnerMedia Assets With Discovery
summary: Deal would complete telecom giant's retreat from the media business, which included owning cable channels such as HBO and CNN. AT&T Inc. and Discovery Inc. reached a deal to combine their media assets into a new, publicly traded company, unwinding the telecom company's big bet on entertainment after less than three years.

title: Kodak Says New York Attorney General Has Threatened Lawsuit
summary: At issue are a series of stock purchases made by Kodak's CEO ahead of a planned $765 million deal with the U.S. government. Eastman Kodak Co. on Monday said the New York attorney general has threatened to sue the company and its chief executive over a series of stock purchases made by the executive ahead of a planned $765 million deal with the U.S. government to produce drug ingredients.

title: AT&T's Hollywood Ending Erased Billions in Value
summary: Resume Subscription. Three years ago, AT&T Inc. executives were in a federal courthouse fighting the Justice Department to defend their takeover of Time Warner Inc., a more than $80 billion foray into the entertainment business.
